awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraining the temporal evolution of mantle plume contributions to magmatism in the Turkana Depression
awd_abstract_narration:
The process by which the Earth's continental masses split apart to form new oceans is a central tenet of the plate tectonic paradigm. This project focuses on one of the most important features of continental rifted margins - that is the origin of magmas that are erupted within them. While the construction of oceanic crust late in the rifting cycle requires voluminous magmatic activity, there is a growing understanding that magmas also play a pivotal role earlier in the rifting process. Infiltration of magma into the tectonic plate during rift initiation contributes to the rifting process by weakening and focusing strain. However, the process of melt generation during rifting is poorly constrained. East Africa, the geographic focus area of this research project, is the classic example of a continental rift, and insights gained here have global application. Using geochemical techniques on erupted lavas, this project seeks to determine how magma is produced during continental rifting to improve our understanding of the range of contributions from various mechanisms to generate melt. The results will have important implications for understanding magma generation during the initiation and evolution of rifting, and for our understanding of the contribution of lithospheric, upper mantle, and deep mantle sources. Constraining the mechanisms which control the structure and characteristics of rifted margins has broad societal and economic benefits given much of the world's population and hydrocarbon resources and located along rifted continental margins.

This proposal outlines a plan to obtain new geochemical and geochronological data in order to better understand the sources of rift lavas. The temporal variation in the role of a mantle plume and easily melted portions of the lithosphere in melt generation processes will be evaluated. The study region, in the eastern branch of the East African Rift, is a focus site of the GeoPRISMS program. The hypothesis to be tested is that volcanism in the study region has been plume influenced since the Eocene. This hypothesis will be addressed by examining the following questions: (1) What are the geochemical characteristics of the different sources of rift lavas; and (2) how have contributions from these source(s) changed over time? These questions will be addressed through a geochronological, geochemical, and paleomagnetic study of lavas with a goal to construct a detailed geochemical characterization of the sources of within-rift lavas and determine their spatial distribution and temporal variation. The study of continental rift lavas throughout the long-lived extensional process along the East African Rift has the potential to improve understanding of the range of contributions from various melt generation mechanisms. While many studies focus on isolated periods of melt production, the work proposed here would examine the temporal development of melt reservoirs and how contributions from these reservoirs evolve over time as rifting matures. Establishing how "fundamental rifting processes, and feedbacks between them, evolve in time and space" is one of the four key Rift Initiation and Evolution questions identified in the GeoPRISMS draft science plan, thus the result of this project will interface with other GeoPRISMS efforts across disciplines to examine rift development. This project has been supported in part by the Office of International Science and Engineering at NSF.

por.por_cntn:
Continental break-up is often thought to begin with the arrival of a mantle plume beneath a continent. The heat and persistent force of the plume makes the continent stretch to the point that it begins rifting and produce volcanism. With continued rifting and extension, continental volcanism can transition to oceanic volcanism, producing new seafloor over which water can collect and form a sea. The best example of this process happening on the Earth today is the East African Rift. In this region, massive outpourings of flood basalt lavas at ~30 Ma marks the historically recognized arrival of the Afar mantle plume. The flood basalts are located in modern day northwest Ethiopia, Djibouti, Eritrea, Yemen, and Saudi Arabia. When the flood basalts erupted, these regions were connected continuously and, after the arrival of the Afar plume, continental rifting created the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden, and the East African Rift System.

While the Afar plume is widely recognized as the event that initiated continental rifting in this region, it is not responsible for the first volcanism in the East African Rift. The first volcanism occurred in northern Kenya and southern Ethiopia ~35-45 Ma. This volcanic episode also produced outpourings of flood basalt west of Lake Turkana in Kenya. This episode of volcanism did not initiate continental rifting, but the region has been volcanically active since then and through to the present. This study investigated the mafic lavas in this region to understand how they formed. Specifically, we investigated the most mafic (>7 weight % MgO) Eocene lavas erupted in southern Ethiopia and northern Kenya near Lake Turkana. We also considered the similarities and differences of those lavas to subsequent Lake Turkana lavas erupted during the Oligocene (~30 Ma) and the Miocene (~ 24 Ma).  We use major element, trace element, rhenium (Re) isotopes, and osmium (Os) isotopes from 27 lavas to understand what melted to produce volcanism in each time period and location, and to determine if the sources are similar or different to lavas produced by melting the Afar mantle plume.

Broadly, there are one to two sources melting to produce lavas in southern Ethiopia and the Lake Turkana area (Kenya). Trace elements demonstrate that the Earth's mantle melted to produce all of the lavas in the region but that continental crust only contributed to some of those lavas. Interestingly, the composition of the mantle melting to produce volcanism is different beneath southern Ethiopia and Lake Turkana. Specifically, Re-Os isotopes demonstrate that the mantle beneath southern Ethiopia is depleted, meaning it experienced a much older melting event prior to generating the Eocene lavas. In contrast, Eocene Lake Turkana lavas were derived from an enriched (non-depleted) mantle, and that mantle continued to contribute to Lake Turkana lavas in the Oligocene and Miocene. This enriched source is distinct in trace element and Re-Os isotopic composition from the Afar mantle plume.

This project supported an early-career scientist and an undergraduate research student. The undergraduate student gained valuable professional experience as they learned sample preparation techniques and how to work with samples and acids in a clean room environment. The student also learned how to work with and integrate several datasets and present their findings at an international conference. A manuscript detailing the results of this study is being constructed.

 


Last Modified: 12/26/2021
Modified by: Wendy R Nelson
